messages.text:
Did I misread the doc somehow? `string(nothing)` seems to work perfectly fine
```help?> string(nothing)
  string(xs...)

  Create a string from any values, except nothing, using the print function.

  string should usually not be defined directly. Instead, define a method print(io::IO, x::MyType). If string(x) for a
  certain type needs to be highly efficient, then it may make sense to add a method to string and define print(io::IO,
  x::MyType) = print(io, string(x)) to ensure the functions are consistent.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> string("a", 1, true)
  "a1true"

julia> string(nothing)
"nothing"```

Hi guys, is there any known multi-threading issue in Windows 10 (Julia v1.3.1) when running a Julia script via `run` command?

Everything works fine in my colleague's Windows machine when running the script via command line directly, but when calling it via another app, i.e. `run(`julia script.jl`)`  (in this case, script.jl is the multi-threaded script), this just stuck randomly without any pattern (no error message/meaningful insights in debug logs, although I have set JULIA_DEBUG="all"). The script.jl bottlenecks in I/O operation (read/write), so I implemented multi-threading on it. Note that the julia call I ran in both via cli and via another app is exact same command.

I also couldn't replicate this issue in my Ubuntu machine although running it via another app's call. This seems to be a really weird issue since we didn't see this before.

Here's what I'm going to try:
1. Running just `run("script.jl")`  to validate this is not caused by any other part of my app.
2. If that doesn't work it means the issue is with the `run` function on multi-threaded app? So I think I will try updating the Julia version to v1.5.3.
3. If that doesn't solve my issue, then I will try running it on another Windows machine to see if it's the machine specific, or just Windows in general.
Any thoughts on this?
Thanks!

I made a recursive function to extract a value from a JSON given the key for that value:
```function extract(json, key)
    req = []

    for (k, v) in pairs(json)
        if k == key
            println("FOUND $key == $k")
            println("value: $v")
            println("type: $(typeof(v))")
            push!(req, v)
        elseif typeof(v) <: AbstractDict
            extract(v, key)
        end
    end
    req
end```

Is there a style guide for setting up a workspace? I.e. I have a bunch of files with various functions separated logically, and I want to combine the various files. Right now I have one file with a module, that just includes each in sequence, however in each file there is no module specified. I saw <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/best-way-to-structure-julia-code/26591/17> but that's only one piece of it. A c++ project I'd expect `include/`, `src/` and `tst/` for instance, with the same subfolder structure. Is there a julian style folder structure? I'd like to fix good habits in the jump from single file to multiple file julia work.

Should each file have a module? Is there a standard folder structure? Do you place unit test files alongside the source file or in the test directory?

I'd like to avoid reinventing the wheel on this, as I am sure there's some terrible choices I might make accidentally. It seems like placing them wherever, and `include("XXX.jl"); using .XXX` is the approach, where `XXX` is a file local module. Or is this a naive approach? This isn't for a big widely shared project, just personal, but I don't want to get into bad habits.

messages.text:
Can someone tell me why `Float32` is (much) slower than `Float64` here?
```julia> function f(x::AbstractVector{T}) where T
           m = length(x)
           V = Matrix{T}(undef, m, m)
           for j = 1:m
               V[j,1] = one(T)
           end
           for i= 2:m
               for j = 1:m
                   V[j,i] = x[j] * V[j,i-1]
               end
           end
           return V
       end
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> using BenchmarkTools

julia> x = rand(Float64, 100);

julia> y = rand(Float32, 100);

julia> @btime f($x);
  5.656 μs (2 allocations: 78.20 KiB)

julia> @btime f($y);
  21.023 μs (2 allocations: 39.14 KiB)```

I have a function where I would like to move something from runtime to compile-time. It looks similar to this
```function foo(x::Int, y::Val{Z}) where Z
    table = calc_table(Z)
    bar(table, x)
end```
I would like to move the `calc_table` to compile time, since the computation only depends on compile time constants. But the table allocates an array, filling it in, before converting it the returned tuple. I think somehow the allocation means the code is not side-effect free, and so the compiler will not move it to compile time.
How can I tell the compiler "you can consider this a pure function, just go ahead and constant fold it"?

Are the gains from this <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk> bot really worth it? When I expressed that I thought it was obnoxious, the reaction was essentially, "I don't give a @&$%"

Some people agreed. Some people disagreed. I know it bothers me enough that I've distanced myself from Slack because of it (and, to a certain extent, Julia generally and my evangelism for the language for that matter). 

Are the gains worth alienating people like me who may admittedly be in the minority?

Hi! I am trying to write a generic version of a function that takes a parametric type and constructs that type with a _different_ parameter. In more detail, my type hierarchy is roughly:
```abstract type MySupertype{T} end

struct MyType1{T} <: MySupertype{T}
    field::T
end

struct MyType2{T} <: MySupertype{T}
    field::T
end```
I realize the notation here doesn't work, but I want to do something like:
```function my_fn(x::MT{T}) where MT{T} <: MySupertype{T} where T
    return ForwardDiff.gradient(p -> MT(p...), [0.])
end```
Is this possible, or do I need to write a different version of the function for the two possible values of `MT`? Thanks so much!
